categories.title: During Pregnancy
categories.description: Information and tips for a healthy pregnancy

resources.title: What to Expect at Prenatal Visits
resources.summary: Learn about routine checkups and what happens at each trimester
resources.content:
Regular prenatal visits are essential for monitoring your health and your baby's development.

**First Trimester (Weeks 1-12)**
Your first visit is usually the longest. Your provider will review your medical history, perform a physical exam, and order lab tests. You may have an early ultrasound to confirm your due date.

**Second Trimester (Weeks 13-27)**
Visits typically occur every 4 weeks. You'll have the anatomy scan ultrasound around 18-20 weeks. Glucose screening for gestational diabetes usually happens around 24-28 weeks.

**Third Trimester (Weeks 28-40)**
Visits become more frequent - every 2 weeks until 36 weeks, then weekly. Your provider will monitor baby's position and check for signs of labor.

**What to bring:**
- List of questions
- Current medications
- Insurance card
- Support person if desired

resources.title: Nutrition During Pregnancy
resources.summary: Guidelines for eating well and foods to avoid
resources.content:
Good nutrition during pregnancy supports your baby's growth and development.

**Important nutrients:**
- **Folic acid**: 400-800 mcg daily (leafy greens, fortified cereals)
- **Iron**: 27 mg daily (lean meats, beans, spinach)
- **Calcium**: 1000 mg daily (dairy, fortified foods)
- **DHA**: 200-300 mg daily (fish, supplements)

**Foods to avoid:**
- Raw or undercooked meat, fish, and eggs
- Unpasteurized dairy and juices
- High-mercury fish (shark, swordfish, king mackerel)
- Deli meats unless heated until steaming
- Alcohol

**Tips:**
- Eat small, frequent meals to manage nausea
- Stay hydrated with 8-10 glasses of water daily
- Take your prenatal vitamin consistently

resources.title: When to Call Your Provider
resources.summary: Warning signs that need immediate attention
resources.content:
Some symptoms during pregnancy require prompt medical attention.

**Call immediately for:**
- Vaginal bleeding
- Severe abdominal pain
- Severe headache that doesn't go away
- Vision changes (blurry, spots, flashing lights)
- Sudden swelling of face or hands
- Decreased fetal movement
- Signs of labor before 37 weeks
- Leaking fluid from vagina
- Fever over 100.4¬∞F

**Contact your provider for:**
- Persistent nausea/vomiting
- Painful urination
- Unusual vaginal discharge
- Concerns about baby's movement

**UCI Labor & Delivery:** (949) 824-8200
**Emergency:** Call 911

categories.title: Labor & Delivery
categories.description: Preparing for birth and what to expect

resources.title: Signs of Labor
resources.summary: How to know when labor is starting
resources.content:
Recognizing the signs of labor helps you know when to head to the hospital.

**Early signs (days to hours before):**
- "Nesting" urge (burst of energy)
- Loose stools
- Loss of mucus plug
- Backache
- Lightening (baby drops lower)

**True labor signs:**
- Regular contractions that get closer together
- Contractions that don't stop with movement or rest
- Water breaking (may be a gush or trickle)
- Bloody show (mucus tinged with blood)

**5-1-1 Rule for first-time moms:**
Call or come in when contractions are:
- **5** minutes apart
- Lasting **1** minute each
- For **1** hour

**Call immediately if:**
- Water breaks
- Heavy bleeding
- Baby stops moving
- Severe pain

resources.title: What to Pack for the Hospital
resources.summary: Essential items for your hospital stay
resources.content:
Pack your bag around 36 weeks, just in case!

**For labor:**
- ID and insurance cards
- Birth plan (if you have one)
- Comfortable robe or gown
- Grip socks
- Hair ties
- Lip balm
- Phone and charger
- Focal point or comfort items

**For after birth:**
- Going-home outfit (loose and comfortable)
- Nursing bras if breastfeeding
- Toiletries
- Glasses/contacts

**For baby:**
- Going-home outfit
- Car seat (installed and ready)
- Blanket

**For your support person:**
- Snacks
- Change of clothes
- Toiletries
- Entertainment
- Cash for vending machines

**UCI provides:**
- Hospital gown
- Mesh underwear and pads
- Basic toiletries
- Diapers and wipes
- Baby blankets

resources.title: Pain Management Options
resources.summary: Understanding your options for comfort during labor
resources.content:
You have many options for managing labor pain. Discuss these with your provider beforehand.

**Non-medication options:**
- Movement and position changes
- Breathing techniques
- Massage and counter-pressure
- Warm shower or tub (if available)
- Birth ball
- Music and visualization
- TENS unit

**Medication options:**
- **IV pain medication**: Takes edge off, allows movement
- **Epidural**: Numbs from waist down, very effective
- **Nitrous oxide**: Inhaled gas, mild relief
- **Local anesthesia**: For specific areas

**About epidurals:**
- Can be placed once active labor begins
- You'll still feel pressure but not sharp pain
- Allows rest during long labors
- Can be adjusted for pushing

**Remember:**
- Your plan can change during labor
- All options are valid choices
- Your team will support whatever you decide

categories.title: After Baby Arrives
categories.description: Recovery, newborn care, and adjusting to parenthood

resources.title: Your Physical Recovery
resources.summary: What to expect in the weeks after birth
resources.content:
Your body needs time to heal after birth. Be patient with yourself.

**First few days:**
- Vaginal bleeding (lochia) - normal for 4-6 weeks
- Cramping, especially while breastfeeding
- Soreness in perineum or incision area
- Breast engorgement when milk comes in
- Sweating, especially at night

**Recovery tips:**
- Rest as much as possible
- Accept help from others
- Stay hydrated
- Use ice packs for swelling
- Take medications as prescribed
- Move gently to prevent blood clots

**After cesarean:**
- Keep incision clean and dry
- Avoid lifting heavy objects (over 10 lbs) for 6 weeks
- Support your belly when coughing or laughing

**Call your provider if:**
- Fever over 100.4¬∞F
- Heavy bleeding (soaking a pad in 1 hour)
- Severe pain not relieved by medication
- Signs of infection (redness, pus, foul odor)
- Difficulty breathing or chest pain
- Leg pain or swelling (one side)

resources.title: Newborn Care Basics
resources.summary: Essential information for caring for your new baby
resources.content:
Caring for a newborn can feel overwhelming, but you'll learn quickly!

**Feeding:**
- Feed on demand, usually every 2-3 hours
- Look for hunger cues: rooting, hand-to-mouth
- 8-12 feedings per day is normal

**Diapering:**
- Expect 6-8 wet diapers per day once milk comes in
- Clean umbilical stump with water, keep dry
- Fold diaper below stump until it falls off

**Sleep:**
- Newborns sleep 16-17 hours per day in short stretches
- Always place baby on back to sleep
- Keep crib free of loose bedding, toys, bumpers
- Room share (not bed share) for first 6-12 months

**Bathing:**
- Sponge baths only until cord falls off
- 2-3 baths per week is plenty
- Keep room warm

**Normal newborn things:**
- Sneezing (clearing passages)
- Hiccups
- Irregular breathing patterns
- Startle reflex
- Peeling skin

resources.title: Your Postpartum Checkup
resources.summary: What happens at your follow-up appointment
resources.content:
Your postpartum visit is an important check on your recovery.

**When:**
- Usually 4-6 weeks after delivery
- Earlier if you had a cesarean or complications
- May have additional check-ins by phone

**What to expect:**
- Physical exam
- Check incision or perineal healing
- Blood pressure check
- Discussion of birth control options
- Screening for postpartum depression
- Address any concerns or questions

**Topics to discuss:**
- How you're feeling emotionally
- Feeding challenges
- Sleep and fatigue
- Pain or complications
- Return to exercise
- Intimacy and birth control
- Support system

**Prepare by:**
- Writing down questions
- Noting any symptoms or concerns
- Bringing your baby (or arranging childcare)
- Being honest about how you're really feeling

categories.title: Mental Health & Wellness
categories.description: Emotional wellbeing during pregnancy and postpartum

resources.title: Baby Blues vs. Postpartum Depression
resources.summary: Understanding the difference and when to seek help
resources.content:
Mood changes after birth are common, but some symptoms need attention.

**Baby Blues (normal):**
- Affects up to 80% of new parents
- Starts within first few days after birth
- Lasts up to 2 weeks
- Symptoms: mood swings, crying, anxiety, irritability
- Resolves on its own

**Postpartum Depression (needs support):**
- Affects 1 in 7 new parents
- Can start anytime in first year
- Lasts longer than 2 weeks
- Symptoms: persistent sadness, hopelessness, guilt
- Difficulty bonding with baby
- Changes in sleep or appetite
- Thoughts of harming yourself or baby

**Risk factors:**
- History of depression or anxiety
- Difficult pregnancy or birth
- Lack of support
- Major life stressors
- Previous postpartum depression

**Remember:**
- PPD is treatable
- It's not your fault
- Getting help is a sign of strength
- Treatment helps you and your baby

resources.title: Self-Care for New Parents
resources.summary: Practical ways to take care of yourself
resources.content:
Taking care of yourself helps you take care of your baby.

**Sleep when you can:**
- Nap when baby naps
- Take shifts with partner
- Accept help with night feedings if possible

**Nourish your body:**
- Eat regular meals
- Keep easy snacks accessible
- Stay hydrated

**Connect with others:**
- Don't isolate yourself
- Join a new parent group
- Video chat with friends and family
- Accept visitors who offer to help

**Move your body (when cleared):**
- Short walks outside
- Gentle stretching
- Baby-wearing counts as exercise!

**Ask for help:**
- Be specific about what you need
- Let others do household tasks
- Use meal delivery services
- Don't aim for perfection

**Protect your mental health:**
- Limit social media
- Lower your expectations
- Celebrate small wins
- Talk about your feelings

resources.title: Getting Help for Emotional Struggles
resources.summary: Resources and next steps for support
resources.content:
If you're struggling, help is available. You don't have to face this alone.

**Talk to someone:**
- Your OB, midwife, or primary care provider
- Your baby's pediatrician
- A therapist specializing in perinatal mental health

**Crisis resources:**
- **988 Suicide & Crisis Lifeline**: Call or text 988
- **Postpartum Support International**: 1-800-944-4773 (call/text)
- **Emergency**: Call 911

**What treatment looks like:**
- Therapy (talk therapy, CBT)
- Support groups
- Medication (many are safe while breastfeeding)
- Combination approaches

**What to say to your provider:**
- "I'm not feeling like myself"
- "I'm struggling more than I expected"
- "I'm having scary thoughts"
- "I need help"

**Remember:**
- Treatment works
- Most people improve significantly
- You deserve support
- Your baby needs you to be well

resources.title: Getting Started with Breastfeeding
resources.summary: Tips for the first days and weeks
resources.content:
Breastfeeding is natural, but it takes practice for both you and baby.

**First hours:**
- Skin-to-skin contact helps initiate breastfeeding
- Baby may feed or just nuzzle at first
- Colostrum (first milk) is all baby needs initially

**First days:**
- Feed whenever baby shows hunger cues
- Expect 8-12 feedings per day
- Each session may last 10-45 minutes
- Both breasts don't need to be used each time

**Signs of good latch:**
- Wide open mouth with lips flanged out
- Chin touching breast
- Nose slightly away from breast
- No clicking sounds
- No pain after initial latch

**Signs baby is getting enough:**
- 6-8 wet diapers per day by day 4
- Yellow seedy stools
- Weight gain after initial loss
- Satisfied after feedings
- Audible swallowing

**Get help if:**
- Latching is painful
- Baby isn't gaining weight
- You have nipple damage
- Feeding takes over an hour every time

resources.title: Common Breastfeeding Challenges
resources.content:
Many breastfeeding challenges have solutions. Don't give up!

**Sore nipples:**
- Usually from shallow latch
- Apply expressed milk and let air dry
- Use lanolin cream
- Try different positions
- See a lactation consultant

**Engorgement:**
- Feed frequently
- Apply cold compresses between feedings
- Hand express for comfort if needed
- Wear supportive bra

**Low supply concerns:**
- Feed more frequently
- Ensure good latch
- Stay hydrated and nourished
- Consider pumping after feedings
- Most perceived low supply is actually normal

**Mastitis:**
- Flu-like symptoms with breast pain
- Red, hot area on breast
- Continue nursing to clear blockage
- Apply heat before feedings
- See provider‚Äîmay need antibiotics

**Where to get help:**
- Hospital lactation consultants
- Private lactation consultants (IBCLC)
- La Leche League meetings
- Breastfeeding support groups

resources.title: Formula Feeding Basics
resources.content:
Formula is a safe, nutritious option for feeding your baby.

**Choosing formula:**
- Most babies do well on standard cow's milk formula
- Talk to your pediatrician before switching types
- Generic brands are nutritionally equivalent to name brands

**Preparation:**
- Follow package directions exactly
- Use the scoop that comes with the formula
- Use clean water (check if needs to be boiled)
- Prepare one bottle at a time when possible

**Feeding:**
- Hold baby in semi-upright position
- Keep bottle tilted so nipple is full
- Let baby set the pace
- Burp during and after feeding
- Discard unfinished formula after 1 hour

**Amount and frequency:**
- Newborns: 1-3 oz every 2-3 hours
- Increases gradually over first months
- 24-32 oz total per day by one month
- Watch for hunger and fullness cues

**Remember:**
- Formula feeding is a valid choice
- Bonding happens with any feeding method
- Fed is best
